asset.hookText:
Spending a day at Legal Sea Foods in Boston is a real experience. Roger S. Berkowitz, the President and Chief Executive Officer, barely considers himself a restaurateur even though he has over three dozen restaurants along the East Coast of the United States. He says, "I sell fish.  I just happen to do it mostly in a restaurant."

We evolved from a retail fish market and then we got into the restaurant business almost by mistake. But we were absolutely fanatical both quality and quality assurance and so that translated to succeeding generations down the road. It's important to us to know. How the source. Of seafood. Your fisherman in terms of how the hell you're going to get a better product and that's going to translate to a better experience on the plate. We first had inspectors coming in and checking product and then we later set up a laboratory where we did our own shellfish testing as an example so every bit of shellfish now that comes into our plant before goes out to the restaurants is held in quarantine for 24 hours. I think that the real point of differentiation force is that although it sure would be considered a restaurant company we're really a fish company in the restaurant business and so when you change a sort of orientation you can look at things a little differently.
